awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: Molecular Evolution of Bacterial Iron Piracy in Amoeba Hosts
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Environmental microorganisms, like bacteria, can evolve the molecular machinery to become disease pathogens in animal or human hosts. How does this occur? One hypothesis is that the need to survive predation by microeukaryotes, such as amoeba, selects for the evolution of genes that fight eukaryotic immunity. However, one ancient eukaryotic immune response is to deny pathogens access to iron. Successful pathogens have evolved tools to fight against the host to acquire iron. The outcome of this molecular tug of war is critical as iron is a vital micronutrient, required by most organisms for growth and survival. This project focuses on how adaptation to predatory amoeba, specifically the host-pathogen battle for iron has caused the bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila to evolve at the molecular level. The Fellow will recruit and mentor students in research in collaboration with the University of Pittsburgh.  

Host-pathogen conflicts can lead to molecular arms races, where domains of the proteins at the host-pathogen interface are subjected to ongoing cycles of rapid host and pathogen evolution. This project will test the hypothesis that the battle for iron has led iron sequestration genes to rapidly evolve as part of a molecular arms race between Legionella and its natural amoeba hosts. This project takes advantage of the power and utility of the Legionella/Dictyostelium infection model. Specifically, the Fellow will interrogate the evolution of MavN, a protein secreted by Legionella that functions to transport iron from the host cytosol into the Legionella-containing vacuole. The MavN protein shows signatures of rapid evolution and this sequence diversity has phenotypic consequences. These features suggest that MavN might be evolving due to a molecular arms race. This work bridges the current divide between evolutionary microbiology, bioinformatics, and bacteriology, and will enable the Fellow to enhance and develop skills that they will need to establish their own career as an independent researcher. This project will enable the Fellow to gain training in mentoring, scientific rigor, and how to foster inclusive environments in STEM. In addition, the Fellow will engage in efforts designed to increase scientific outreach in the Pittsburgh area by enhancing K-12 STEM curriculum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has three major scientific goals focusing on uncovering how the L. pneumophila protein MavN has evolved to steal iron from host cells. In Aim 1 and 2, I was investigating the role and impact of closely related MavN proteins from other Legionella species. The goal of Aim 3 was to use an unbiased experiment to determine which genes in Legionella are required during infection due to a role maintaining iron stability (iron is an important nutrient for bacteria like Legionella).

I characterized the ability of 7 MavN homologs from closely related Legionella species to complement a mavN deletion mutant during infection of amoeba. I assayed MavN proteins that were very similar to L. pneumophila’s MavN and ones that were more distantly related. I determined that L. walterii’s MavN protein, even though it is 63% identical to L. pnumophila’s MavN, it still has a dramatic inability to rescue replication during an amoeba infection. The MavN of L. waltersii is the closest related MavN to L. pnumophila and is highly conserved across the protein except at three distinct variable regions. Are these variable regions responsible for the L. waltersii phenotype? I generated MavN chimeras (proteins that are made up of parts of MavN from two different species). I have tested a few of these chimeras and found some very interesting phenotypes. Specifically, I have found that variable regions 1 and 3 seem likely to cause the phenotype while variable region 2 had little effect.

                In parallel, I have been working to optimize assays to evaluate how MavN evolution is altering its molecular function. I determined in Aim 1 that these versions of MavN from other Legionella species do not work during infection. Why is this the case? I hypothesized that there are three main reasons why the proteins might be nonfunctional: 1) a lack of protein production (i.e. the protein is not made), 2) the protein might be made but might not have the ability to go to the right area of the cell during infection, 3) maybe these proteins are unable to transport iron as efficiently. I have been working to determine protein production and preliminary data indicates that MavN proteins from functional and nonfunctional species are still being produced at similar levels. I have also been working to optimize the conditions to see the location of MavN during infection. These assays are still very much a work in progress, but they are coming along.

For Aim 3, I tested the ability of iron to rescue the mavN strain during infection. I found 1000 uM Fe3+ was sufficient in some experiments in certain Legionella pneumophila background strains to rescue the intracellular replication defect (although the dynamics of the infection were never recovered to match Wt levels). Armed with this knowledge, I can use this amount of iron and lower levels to see if homologs and chimeras are responding to the iron level or acting as MavN nulls.

Over the lifetime of this PRFB grant, this funding allowed me to participate in a number of outreach programs. These included scientific presentations at Community College of Beaver County, Slippery Rock University, and Penn West University, Edinboro Campus. These talks focused on  MavN and spanned the entirety of my NSF-funded project. In addition, I participated in two inner-city outreach programs in 2024. The first, Spring 2024 Eco Explorers Program, brought fun, interactive, science activities to children aged 7-12. This 6-week program allowed the students to have fun learning about how the DNA code underlies complex traits in a hands-on and engaging way. The second program I did was the Gene Team on the Hill. This afterschool program is designed to prepare inner city high school students for Gene Team in the summer. Gene Team is a month-long research experience at Pitt. For Gene Team on the Hill, which met for 2 hours a week for 5 weeks, our goal was to familiarize students with the fundamentals of microbiology and molecular biology with a focus on engagement and interaction.
